editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The London prodigal. As it was played by the King's majesty's servants. By William Shakespeare,
London. Printed by T. C. for Nathaniel butter, and are to be sold near s. Augustine's gate, at the sign of the pied bull. 1605.

div.head: The London prodigal.
div.stage: Enter old Flowerdale and his brother.

lg.l: Brother from Venice, being thus disguised,
I come to prove the humours of my son:
How hath he born himself since my departure,
I leaving you his patron and his guide?
I'faith brother so, as you will grieve to hear,
And I almost ashamed to report it.
Why how is't brother? what doth he spend
Beyond the allowance I left him?

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: How! beyond that? and far more: why, your exhibition is nothing, he hath spent that, and since hath borrowed, protested with oaths, alleged kindred to wring money from me, by the love I bore his father, by the fortunes might fall upon himself, to furnish his wants ▪ that done, I have had since, his bond, his friend and friend's bond, although I know that he spends is yours; yet it grieves me to see the unbridled wildness that reins over him.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p:
Brother, what is the manner of his life? how is the name of his offences? if they do not relish altogether of damnation, his youth may privilege his wantonness: I myself ran an unbridled course till thirty, nay almost till forty, well, you see how I am: for vice once looked into with the eyes of discretion, and well balanced with the waits of reason, the course past, seems so abominable, that the landlord of himself, which is the heart of his body, will rather entomb himself
in the earth, or seek a new tenant to remain in him, which once settled, how much better are they that in their youth have known all these vices, and left it, than those that knew little, and in their age runs into it? Believe me brother, they that die most virtuous, hath in their youth, lived most vicious, and none knows the danger of the fire, more than he that falls into it: but say, how is the course of his life? let's hear his particulars.

lg.l: Why I'll tell you brother, he is a continual swearer,
And a breaker of his oaths, which is bad.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: I grant indeed to swear is bad, but not in keeping those oaths is better: for who will set by a bad thing?

lg.l: Nay by my faith, I hold this rather a virtue than a vice,
Well, I pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: He is a mighty brawler, and comes commonly by the worst.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: By my faith this is none of the worst neither, for if he brawl and be beaten for it, it will in time make him shun it: for what brings man or child, more to virtue, than correction? What reigns over him else?

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: He is a great drinker, and one that will forget himself.

lg.l: O best of all, vice should be forgotten: let him drink on,
So he drink not churches.
Nay and this be the worst, I hold it rather a happiness in him,
Than any iniquity. Hath he any more attendants?

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Brother, he is one that will borrow of any man.

lg.l: Why you see so doth the sea, it borrows of all the small
Currents in the world, to increase himself.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Ay, but the sea pays it again, and so will never your son.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: No more would the sea neither, if it were as dry as my son.

lg.l: Then brother, I see you rather like these vices in your son,
Than any way condemn them.
Nay mistake me not brother, for though I slur them over now,
As things slight and nothing, his crimes being in the bud,
It would gall my heart, they should ever reign in him.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Ho! who's within ho?

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: That's your son, he is come to borrow more money.

lg.l: For godsake give it out I am dead, see how he'll take it,
Say I have brought you news from his father.
I have here drawn a formal will, as it were from myself,
Which I'll deliver him.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Go too brother, no more: I will.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Uncle, where are you uncle? within,

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Let my cousin in there.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: I am a sailor come from Venice, and my name is Christopher.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: By the lord, in truth uncle.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: In truth would a served cousin, without the lord.

lg.l: By your leave uncle, the lord, is the lord of truth.
A couple of rascals at the gate, set upon me for my purse.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: You never come, but you bring a brawl in your mouth.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: By my truth uncle, you must needs lend me ten pound.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Give my cousin some small beer here.

lg.l: Nay look you, you turn it to a jest now, by this light,
I should ride to Croyden fair, to meet sir Lancelot Spurcock,
I should have his daughter Luce, and for scurvy
Ten pound, a man shall lose nine hundred threescore and
Odd pounds, and a daily friend beside, by this hand uncle 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Why, any thing is true for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: To see now: why you shall have my bond uncle, or Tom Whites, James Brocks: or Nick Hall's, as good rapier and dagger men, as any be in England, let's be damned if we do not pay you, the worst of us all will not damn ourselves for ten pound. A pox often pound.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Cousin, this is not the first time I have believed you.

lg.l: Why trust me now, you know not what may fall:
If one thing were but true, I would not greatly care,
I should not need ten pound, but when a man cannot be believed, there's it.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Why what is it cousin?

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Marry this uncle, can you tell me if the katernhue be come home or no?

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: I marry is't.

lg.l: By God I thank you for that news.
What is't in the pool can you tell?

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: It is; what of that?

lg.l: What? why then I have six pieces of vellet sent me
I'll give you a piece uncle ▪ for thus said the letter,
A piece of ash-colour, a three piled black, a coloured decoy,
A crimson, a sad green, and a purple: yes i'faith.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: From whom should you receive this?

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: From who? why from my father? with commendations to you uncle, and thus he writes: I know saith he, thou hast much troubled thy kind uncle, whom god-willing at my return I will see amply satisfied: amply, I remember was the very word; so God help me.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Have you the letter here?

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Yes I have the letter here, here is the letter: no, yes, no let me see, what breeches wore I a Saturday: let me see, a Tuesday, my calymanka, a Wednesday, my peach colour satin, a Thursday my velour, a Friday my callymanka again, a Saturday, let me see a Saturday, for in those breeches I wore a Saturday is the letter: oh my ryding breeches ankle, those that you thought had been vellet, in those very breeches is the letter.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: When should it be dated??

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Mary didicimo tersios septembris, no no, trydisimo tersios octobris, I octobris so it is.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Dicditimo tersios octobris: and here receive I a letter that your father died in June: how say you Kester?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Yes truly sir, your father is dead, these hands of mine hope to wind him.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Dead?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: I sir dead.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: 'Sblood, how should my father come dead?

lg.l: I'faith sir according to the old proverb,
The child was born: and cried, became man,
After fell sick, and died.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Nay cousin do not take it so heavily.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Nay I cannot weep you extempore, marry some two or three days hence, I shall weep without any stintance. But I hope he died in good memory.

lg.l: Very well sir, and set down every thing in good order,
And the Katherine and hue you talked of, I came over in:
And I saw all the bills of lading, and the vellet
That you talked of, there is no such aboard.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: By God I assure you, than there is knavery abroad.

lg.l: I'll be sworn of that: there's knavery abroad,
Although there were never a piece of vellet in Venice.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: I hope he died in good estate.

lg.l: To the report of the world he did, and made his will,
Of which I am an unworthy bearer.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: His will, have you his will?

lg.l: Yes sir, and in the presence of your uncle,
I was willed to deliver it.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: I hope cousin, now God hath blessed you with wealth, you will not be unmindful of me.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: I'll do reason uncle, yet i'faith I take the denial of this ten pound very hardly.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Nay I denied you not.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: By God you denied me directly.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: I'll be judge by this goodfellow.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Not directly sir.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Why he said he would lend me none, and that had wont to be a direct denial, if the old phrase hold: well uncle, come we'll fall to the legacies, in the name of God, amen.
Item, I bequeath to my brother Flowerdale, three hundred pounds, to pay such trivial debts as I owe in London.
Item, to my son Mat Flowerdale, I bequeath two bail of false dice, videlicet, high men, and lo men, fullomes, stop cater trays, and other bones of function.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: 'Sblood what doth he mean by this?

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Proceed cousin.

sp.speaker: Flow.

lg.l: These precepts I leave him, let him borrow of his oath,
For of his word nobody will trust him.
Let him by no means marry an honest woman,
For the other will keep herself.
Let him steal as much as he can, that a guilty conscience
May bring him to his destinate repentance,

sp.p: I think he means hanging. And this were his last will and testament, the devil stood laughing at his bed's feet while he made it. 'sblood, what doth he think to fop of his posterity with paradoxes.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: This he made sir with his own hands.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Ay, well, nay come good uncle, let me have this ten pound, imagine you have lost it, or robbed of it, or misreckoned yourself so much: any way to make it come easily off, good uncle.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Not a penny.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: I'faith lend it him sir; I myself have an estate in the city worth twenty pound, all that I'll engage for him, he saith it concerns him in a marriage.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: I marry doth it, this is a fellow of some sense, this: come good uncle.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Will you give your word for it Kester?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: I will sir, willingly.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Well cousin, come to me some hour hence, you shall have it ready.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Shall I not fail?

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: You shall not, come or send.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Nay I'll come myself.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: By my troth, would I were your worship's man.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: What wouldst thou serve?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Very willingly sir.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Why I'll tell thee what thou shalt do, thou saith thou hast twenty pound, go into Burchin lane, put thyself into clothes, thou shalt ride with me to Croyden fair.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: I thank you sir, I will attend you.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Well uncle, you will not fail me an hour hence?

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: I will not cozen.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: What's thy name Kester?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: I sir.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Well, provide thyself: uncle farewelll till anon.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Brother, how do you like your son?

lg.l: I'faith brother, like a mad unbridled colt,
Or as a hawk, that never stooped to lure:
The one must be tamed with an iron bit,
The other must be watched, or still she is wild,
Such is my son, awhile let him be so:
For counsel still is folly's deadly foe.
I'll serve his youth, for youth must have his course,
For being restrained, it makes him ten times worse:
His pride, his riot, all that may be named,
Time may recall, and all his madness tamed.

div.stage: Enter sir Launcelot, master Weathercock, Daffidill, Artichoake, Luce, and Frank.

lg.l: Sirrah Artichoake, get you home before,
And as you proved yourself a calf in buying,
Drive home your fellow calves that you have bought.

sp.speaker: Artichoake
sp.p: Yes forsooth, shall not my fellow Daffidill go along with me.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: No sir, no, I must have one to wait on me.

lg.l: Daffidill, farewell good fellow Daffidill,
You may see mistress, I am set up by the halves,
In steed of waiting on you, I am sent to drive home calves.
I'faith Francke, I must turn away this Daffidill,
He's grown a very foolish saucy fellow.
Indeed la father, he was so since I had him:
Before he was wise enough, for a foolish servingman.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: But what say you to me sir Lancelot?

lg.l: O, about my daughters, well I will go forward,
Here's two of them God save them: but the third,
Oh she's a stranger in her course of life,
She hath refused you master Weathercock.
I by the rood sir Lancelot that she hath,
But had she tried me, she should a found a man of me indeed.
Nay be not angry sir, at her denial,
she hath refused seven of the worshipfulst and worthiest housekeepers this day in Kent:
Indeed she will not marry I suppose.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: The more fool she.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: What is it folly to love charity?

lg.l: No mistake me not sir Lancelot,
But 'tis an old proverb, and you know it well,
That women dying maids, lead apes in hell.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: That's a foolish proverb, and a false.

lg.l: By the mass I think it be, and therefore let it go:
But who shall marry with mistress Frances?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By my troth they are talking of marrying me sister.

lg.l: Peace, let them talk:
Fools may have leave to prattle as they walk.
Sentences still sweet mistress,
You have a wit, and it were your alabaster.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I'faith and thy tongue trips Trenchmore.

lg.l: No of my knighthood, not a shuter yet:
Alas God help her silly girl, a fool, a very fool:
But there's the other black-brows a shrewd girl,
She hath wit at will, and suitors two or three:
Sir Arthur Greenshield one, a gallant knight,
A valiant soldier, but his power but poor.
Then there's young Oliver, the Devonshire lad,
A wary fellow, marry full of wit,
And rich by the rood, but there's a third all air,
Light as a feather, changing as the wind: young Flowerdale.
O he sir, he's a desperate dick indeed.
Bar him your house.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Fie not so, he's of good parentage.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: By my fay and so he is, and a proper man.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I proper enough, had he good qualities.

lg.l: I marry, there's the point sir Lancelot:
For there's an old saying,
Be he rich, or be he poor,
Be he high, or be he low:
Be he born in barn or hall,
'Tis manners makes the man and all.

sp.p: You are in the right master Weathercock.
Soul, I think I am sure crossed,

Or wi●ht with an owl, I have haunted them: inn after inn, booth, after booth, yet cannot find them, ha yonder they are, that's she, I hope to God 'tis she, nay I know 'tis she now, for she treads her shoe a little awry.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Where is this ●inne? we are passed it Daffidill.

sp.speaker: Daffidill.
sp.p: The good sign is here sir, but the back gate is before.

sp.speaker: Ciuet.
sp.p: Save you sir, I pray may I borrow a piece of a word with you?

sp.speaker: Daff.
sp.p: No pieces sir.

lg.l: Why then the whole.
I pray sir, what may yonder gentlewomen be?

sp.speaker: Daff.
sp.p: They may be ladies sir, if the destinies and mortality work.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: What's her name sir.

sp.speaker: Daff.
sp.p: Mistress Frances Spurcock, sir Lancelot-spurcock's daughter.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: Is she a maid sir?

lg.l: You may ask Pluto, and dame Proserpine that:
I would be loath to be ridelled sir.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: Is she married I mean sir?

sp.speaker: Daff.
sp.p: The fates knows not yet what shoemaker shall make her wedding shoes.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: I pray where inn you sir? I would be very glad to bestow the wine of that gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Daff.
sp.p: At the George sir.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Daff.
sp.p: I pray your name sir?

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: My name is master Civet sir.

sp.speaker: Daff.
sp.p: A sweet name, God be with you good master Civet.

lg.l: A, have w● spied you stout s. George?
For all your dragon, you had best sells good wine:
That needs no 〈◊〉 - ivy-bush, well, we'll not sit by it,
As you do on your horse, this room shall serve:
Drawer, let me have sack for us old men:
For these girls and knaves small wines are best,
a pint of sack, no more.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: A quart of sack in the three tons,

lg.l: A pint, draw but a pint daffidill,
Call for wine to make yourselves drink.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And a cup of small beer, and a cake good daffidill.

lg.l: How now, fie, sit in the open room, now good sir
Lancelot, and my kind friend worshipful master Weathercock,
What at your pint, a quart for shame.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Nay Royster by your leave we will away.

lg.l: Come, gives some music, we'll go dance,
Begone sir Lancelot, what, and fair day too?

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: 'Twere foully done, to dance within the fair.

sp.speaker: Flow.

lg.l: Nay if you say so, fairest of all fairs,
Then I'll not dance, a pox upon my tailor,
He hath spoilt me a peach colour satin shute,

sp.p: Cut upon cloth of silver, but if ever the rascal serve me such another trick, I'll give him leave i'faith to put me in the calendar of fools: and you, and you, sir Lancelot; and master Weathercock, my goldsmith too on tother side, I bespoke thee luce, a carcanet of gold, and thought thou shouldst a had it for a fairing, and the rogue puts me in rearages for orient pearl: but thou shalt have it by Sunday night wench.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Sir, here is one hath sent you a pottle of Rhenish wine, brewed with rose-water.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: To me?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: No sir to the knight; and desires his more acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: To me? what's he that proves so kind?

sp.speaker: Daff.
sp.p: I have a trick to know his name sir,
He hath a month's mind here to mistress Frances, his name is master Civet.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Call him in daffidill.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: O I know him sir, he is a fool,
But reasonable rich, his father was one of these lease-mongers, these corn-monger, these money-mongers, but he never had the wit to be a whoremonger.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I promise you sir, you are at too much charge.

sp.speaker: Cyuet.
sp.p: The charge is small charge sir,
I thank God my father left me wherewithal, if it please you sir, I have a great mind to this gentlewoman here in the way of marriage.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I thank you sir: please you come to Lewsome to my poor house, you shall be kindly welcome: I knew your father, he was a wary husband: to pay here drawer.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: All is paid sir: this gentleman hath paid all.

lg.l: I'faith you do us wrong,
But we shall live to make amends ere long:
Master Flowerdale, is that your man?

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Yes faith, a good old knave.

lg.l: Nay then I think you will turn wise,
Now you take such a servant:
Come, you'll ride with us to Lewsome, let's away,
'Tis scarce two hours to the end of day.

div.stage: Enter sir Arthur Green-shood, Olyver, lieutenant and soldiers.

lg.l: Lieutenant, lead your soldiers to the ships,
There let them have their coats, at their arrival
They shall have pay: farewell, look to your charge.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Ay, we are now sent away, and cannot so much as speak with our friends.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: No man whate'er you used a zutch a fashion, thick you cannot take your leave of your vreens.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Fellow no more, lieutenant lead them off.

lg.l: Well, if I have not my pay and my clothes,
I'll venture a running away though I hang fort.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Away sirrah, charm your tongue.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Been and you a presser sir?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I am a commander sir under the King.

lg.l: 'Sfoot man, and you be ne'er zutch a commander
Should a spoken with my vreens before I chid ago, so should.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Content yourself man, my authority will stretch to press so good a man as you.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p:
Press me? I devye, press scoundrels, and thy messels:
press me, chee scorns thee i'faith: for seest thee, here's a worship full knight knows, cha● not to be pressed by thee.

div.stage: Enter sir Lancelet weather cock, young Flowerdale, old Flowerdale, Luce, Frank.

lg.l: Sir Arthur, welcome to Lewsome, welcome by my troth,
What's the matter man, why are you vexed?

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Why man he would press me.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: O fie sir Arthur, press him? he is man of reckoning.

lg.l: I that he is sir Arthur, he hath the nobles,
The golden ruddocks he.
The fitter for the wars: and were he not in favour
With your worships, he should see,
That I have power to press so good as he.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Chill stand to the trial, so Chill.

lg.l: I marry shall he, press-cloth and karsy,
White pot and drowsen broth: tut, tut, he cannot.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Well sir, though you see ulouten cloth and karsy, chee a zeene zutch a karsy coat wear out the town sick a zilken jacket, as thick a one you wear.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Well sed ulitan ulattan.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: A and well said cocknel, and boe-bell too: what dost think Cham a vearde of thy zilken coat, no ●er vere thee.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Nay come no more, be all lovers and friends.

sp.speaker: Vvea.
sp.p: I 'tis best so, good master Olyver.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Is your name master Oliver I pray you?

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: What tit and be tit, and grieve you.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: No burr I de gladly know if a man might not have a foolish plot out of master Oliver to work upon.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Work thy plots upon me, stand aside , work thy foolish plots upon me, Chil so use them, thou wert never so used since thy dame bound thy head, work upon me?

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Let him come, let him come.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p:
Zyrrha, zyrrha, if it were not vor shame, chee would a
given thee zutch a whister poop under the ear, chee would a made thee a vanged another at my feet: stand aside let me lose, Cham all of a ulaming firebrand; stand aside.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Well I forbear you for your friend's sake.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Avig for all my vreens, dost thou tell me of my vreens?

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: No more good master Oliver, no more sir Arthur, and maiden, here in the sight of all your suitors, every man of worth, I'll tell you whom I fainest would prefer to the hard bargain of your marriage bed: shall I be plain among you gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Artichoke
sp.p: I sir 'tis best.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Then sy●, first to you, I do confess you a most gallant knight, a worthy soldier, and an honest man: but honesty maintains a french-hood, goes very seldom in a chain of gold, keeps a small train of servants: hath few friends: and for this wild oats here, young Flowerdale, I will not judge, God can work miracles, but he were better make a hundred new, then thee a thrifty and an honest one.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Believe me he hath bitten you there, he hath touched you to the quick, that hath he.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Woodcock a my side, why master Weathercock you know I am honest, howsoever trifles.

lg.l: Now by my troth, I know no otherwise,
Oh your old mother was a dame indeed:
Heaven hath her soul, and my wives too I trust:
And your good father, honest gentleman,
He is gone a journey as I hear, far hence.
I God be praised, he is far enough,
He is gone a pilgrimage to paradise.
And left me to cut a caper against care,
Luce look on me that am as light as air.
I'faith I like not shadows, bubbles, broth,
I hate a light a love, as I hate death.
Girl hold thee there: look on this Devonshire lad:
Fat, fair, and lovely, both in purse and person.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Well sir, Cham as the lord hath made me, you know me well yvine, Cha have threescore pack a kersey, and blackem hall, and chief credit beside, and my fortunes may be so good as another's, zoe it may.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: 'Tis you I love, whatsoever others say?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Thanks fairest.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: What wouldst thou have me quarrel with him ▪

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Do but say he shall hear from you.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Yet gentleman, howsoever I prefer this Devonshire shuter,
I'll enforce no love, my daughter shall have liberty to choose whom she likes best, in your love shute proceed:
Not all of you, but only one must speed.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: You have said well: indeed right well.

sp.speaker: Artichoke
sp.p: Mistress here's one would speak with you, my fellow Daffidill hath him in the cellar already, he knows him, he met him at Croyden fair.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: O I remember a little man.

sp.speaker: Artichoke
sp.p: I a very little man.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: And yet a proper man.

sp.speaker: Artichoke
sp.p: A very proper, very little man.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: His name is monsieur civet.

sp.speaker: Artichoke
sp.p: The same sir.

lg.l: Come gentlemen if other suitors come,
My foolish daughter will be fitted too:
But Delia my saint, no man dare move.

div.stage: Exit at all but young Flowerdale and Olyver, and old Flowerdale.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Hark you sir, a word.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: What ha an you to say to me now?

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Ye shall hear from me, and that very shortly.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Is that all, vare thee well, chee vere thee not, a vig.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: What if should come more? I am fairly dressed.

lg.l: I do not mean that you shall meet with him,
But presently we'll go and draw a will;
Where we'll set down land, that we never saw,
and we will have it of so large a sum,
Sir Lancelot shall entreat you take his daughter:
This being formed, give it master Weathercock,
And make sir Lancelot's daughter heir of all:
And make him swear, never to show the will
To any one, until that you be dead,
This done, the foolish changing weathercock,
Will straight discourse unto sir Lancelot,
The form and tenor of your testament,
Nor stand to pause of it, be ruled by me:
What will ensue, that shall you quickly see.
Come let's about it: if that a will sweet Kit,
Can get the wench, I shall renown thy wit.
Mistress still froward?
No kind looks unto your Daffidill, now by the gods.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Away you foolish knave, let my hand go.

lg.l: There is your hand, but this shall go with me:
My heart is thine, this is my true love's fee.
I'll have your coat stripped o'er your ears for this,
You saucy rascal.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: How now maid, what is the news with you?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Your man is something saucy.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Go too sirrah, I'll talk with you anon.

lg.l: Sir I am a man to be talked withal,
I am no horse I trow:
I know my strength, then no more than so.

sp.speaker: Vvea.
sp.p: A by the matkins, good sir Lancelot, I saw him the other day hold up the bucklers, like an Hercules, i'faith God a mercy lad, I like thee well.

lg.l: Ay, I like him well, go sirrah fetch me a cup of wine,
Th●● ere I part with master Weathercock,
We may drink down our farewell in French wine.
I thank you sir, I thank you friendly knight,
I'll come and visit you, by the mouse-foot I will:
In the mean time, take heed of cutting Flowerdale,
he is a desperate dick I warrant you.
He is, he is: fill daffidill, fill me some wine, ha, what wears he on his arm?
My daughter Lace's bracelet, i●is the same:
Ha to you master Weathercock.

sp.speaker: Vvea.
sp.p: I thank you sir ▪ here Daffidill, an honest fellow and a tall thou art: well, I'll take my leave good knight, and hope to have you and all your daughters at my poor house, in good sooth I must.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Thanks master Weathercock, I shall be bold to trouble you be sure.

sp.speaker: Vvea.
sp.p: And welcome, heartily farewell.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Sirrah I saw my daughters wrong, and withal her bracelet on your arm, off with it: and with it my livery too, have I care to see my daughter matched with men of worship, and are you grown so bold? Go sirrah from my house, or I'll whip you hence.

lg.l: I'll not be whipped sir, there's your livery. (Exit Daffidill.
This is a servingman's reward, what care I,
I have means to trust too: I scorn service I.
I a lusty knave, but I must let him go,
Our servants must be taught, what they should know.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Sir, as I am a maid, I do affect you above any shuter that I have, although that soldiers scarce knows how to love.

lg.l: I am a soldier, and a gentleman,
Knows what belongs to war, what to a lady:
What man offends me, that my sword shall right:
What woman loves me, I am her faithful knight.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I neither doubt your valour, nor your love, but there be some that bears a soldier's form, that swears by him they never think upon, goes swaggering up and down from house to house, crying God pays: and.

lg.l: I'faith lady I'll descry you such a man,
Of them there be many which you have spoke off,
that bear the name and shape of soldiers,
Yet God knows very seldom saw the war:
That haunt your taverns, and your ordinaries,
Your alehouses sometimes, for all alike
To uphold the brutish humour of their minds,
Being marked down, for the bondmen of despair:
Their mirth begins in wine, but ends in blood,
Their drink is clear, but their conceits are mud.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Yet these are great gentlemen soldiers.

lg.l: No they are wretched slaves,
Whose desperate lives doth bring them timeless graves.
Both for yourself, and for your form of life,
If I may choose, I'll be a soldier's wife.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: And tyt trust to it so then.

lg.l: Assure yourself,
You shall be married with all speed we may:
One day shall serve for Frances and for luce.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Why che wood vain know the time, for providing wedding raiments.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Why no more but this, first get your assurance made, touching my daughter's jointure, that dispatched, we will in two days make provision.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Why man Chil have the writings made by tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Tomorrow be it then, let's meet at the King's head in Fish-street.

lg.l: No fie man no, let's meet at the rose at Temple-bar,
That will be nearer your counsellor and mine.
At the rose, be it then the hour nine,
He that comes last, forfeits a pint of wine.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: A pint is no payment, let it be a whole quart, or nothing.

sp.speaker: Artichoke
sp.p: Master, here is a man would speak with master o●, he comes from young master Flowerdale.
Why Chill speak with him, Chill speak with him.

lg.l: Nay son Oliver, I'll surely see,
What young Flowerdale hath sent to you.
I pray God it be no quarrel.

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: Why man if he quarrel with me, Chill give him his hands full.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: God save you good sir Lancelot.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Welcome honest friend.

lg.l: To you and yours my master wisheth health,
But unto you sir this, and this he sends:
There is the length sir of his rapier,
And in that paper shall you know his mind.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Here Chill meet him my vreend, Chill meet him.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Meet him, you shall not meet the ruffian fie.

lg.l: And I do not meet him, Chill give you leave to call
M● cut, where is't sirrah? where is't? where is't?
The letter shows both the time and place,
And if you be a man, then keep your word.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Sir he shall not keep his word, he shall not meet.

lg.l: Why let him choose, he'll be the better known
For a base rascal, and reputed so.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Zyrrha, zyrrha: and 'twere not an old fellow, and sent after an arrant, Chil give thee something, but chud be no money: but hold thee, for I see thou art somewhat testorne, hold thee, there's vorty shillings, bring thy master a veeld, Chil give thee vorty more, look thou bring him, Chil mall him tell him, Chill mar his dancing trestles, Chil use him, he was ne'er so used since his dam bound his head, Chill make him for capering any more chy vor thee.

lg.l: You seem a man, stout and resolute,
And I will so report, whate'er befall.
And fall out ill, assure thy master this,
I'll make him fly the land, or use him worse.
My master sir, deserves not this of you,
And that you'll shortly find.
Thy master is an unthrift, you a knave,
And I'll attach you first, next clap him up:
Or have him bound unto his good behaviour.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: I wood you were a sprite if you do him any harm for this: and you do, chil ne'er see you, nor any of yours, while Chill have eyes open: what do you think, Chil be abaffelled up and down the town for a mesel, and a scoundrel, no chy bor you: zyrrha Chil come, zay no more, Chil come tell him.

lg.l: Well sir, my master deserves not this of you,
And that you'll shortly find.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: No matter, he's an unthrift, I defy him.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: No, gentle son, let me know the place.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Now chy vore you.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: Let me see the note.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Nay, Chill watch you for zucth a trick.
But if che meet him zoe, if not, zoe: Chill make him know me, or Chill know why I shall not, Chill vare the worse.

lg.l: What will you then neglect my daughter's love?
Venture your state and hers, for a loose brawl?

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Why man, Chill not kill him, marry Chill veze him too, and again; and zoe God be with you father.
What man, we shall met tomorrow.

lg.l: Who would a thought he had been so desperate.
Come forth my honest servant Artichoake.

sp.speaker: Artichoake
sp.p: Now, what's the matter? some brawl towards, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: Go get me thy sword bright scoured, thy buckler mended, oh for that knave, that villain Daffidill would have done good service. But to thee.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Ay, this is the tricks of all you gentlemen, when you stand in need of a good fellow. O for that Daffidill, oh where is he? but if you be angry, and it be but for the wagging of a straw, then out a doors with the knave, turn the coat over his ears. This is the humour of you all.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: O for that knave, that lusty Daffidill.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Why there 'tis now: our years wages and our vails will scarce pay for broken swords and bucklers that we use in our quarrels. But I'll not fight if daffodil be a tother side, that's flat.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: 'Tis no such matter man, get weapons ready, and be at London ere the break of day: watch near the lodging of the Devonshire youth, but be unseen: and as he goes out, as he will go out, and that very early without doubt.

lg.l: What would you have me draw upon him,
As he goes in the street?
Not for a world man: into the fields.
For to the field he goes, there to meet the desperate Flowerdale,
Take thou the part of Olyver my son, for he shall be my son,
And marry luce: dost understand me knave?

sp.speaker: Artichoke
sp.p: I sir I do understand you, but my young mistress might be better provided in matching with my fellow Daffidill.

sp.speaker: Lance.

lg.l: No more; Daffidill is a knave:
That Daffidill is a most notorious knave.

sp.p: Master Weathercock you come in happy time, the desperate Flowerdale hath writ a challenge: and who think you must answer it? but the Devonshire man, my son Oliver.

lg.l: Marry I am sorry for it good sir Lancelot,
But if you will be ruled by me, we'll stay the fury.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: As how I pray?

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Marry I'll tell you, by promising young Flowerdale the red lipped Luce.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I'll rather follow her unto her grave.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: I sir Lancelot I would have thought so too, but you and I have been deceived in him, come read this will, or deed, or what you call it, I know not: come, come, your spectacles I pray.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Nay I thank God, I see very well.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Marry God bless your eyes, mine hath been dim almost this thirty years,

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Ha what is this? what is this?

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Nay there is true love indeed, he gave it to me but this very morn, and bid me keep it unseen from any one, good youth, to see, how men may be deceived.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Passion of me, what a wretch am I to hate this loving youth, he hath made me, together with my luce 〈◊〉 loves so dear, executors of all his wealth.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: All, all good man, he hath given you all.

lg.l: Three ships now in the straits, and homeward bound,
Two lordships of two hundred pound a year:
The one in Wales, the other in Gloucestershire:
Debts and accounts, are thirty thousand pound,
plate, money, jewels, 16. thousand more,
Two housen furnished well in Coleman street:
Beside whatsoever his uncle leaves to him,
Being of great demeans and wealth at Peckham.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: How like you this good knight? how like you this?

lg.l: I have done him wrong, but now 〈◊〉 make amends,
The Devonshire man shall whistle for a wife,
He marry luce, Luce shall be Flowerdale's.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Why that is friendly said, let's ride to London and prevent their match, by promising your daughter to that lovely lad.

lg.l: We'll ride to London, or it shall not need,
We'll cross to Dedfort-strand, and take a boat:
Where be these knaves? what Artichoake, what fop?

sp.speaker: Artichoke
sp.p: Here be the very knaves, but not the merry knaves.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Here take my cloak, I'll have a walk to Dedford.

sp.speaker: Artichoke
sp.p: Sir we have been scouring of our swords and bucklers for your defence.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Defence me no defence, let your sword's rust, I'll have no fighting: ay, let blows alone, bid Delia see all things be in readiness against the wedding, we'll have two at once, and that will save charges master Weathercock.

sp.speaker: Artichoke
sp.p: Well we will do 〈◊〉 sir.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: By my truth this is good luck, I thank God for this, in good sooth I have even my heart's desire: sister 〈◊〉, now I may boldly call you so, for your father hath frank and freely given me his daughter Francke.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I by my troth Tom, thou hast my good will too, for I thank God I longed for a husband, and would I might never stir, for one his name was Tom.

sp.speaker: Delia.
sp.p: Why sister now you have your wish.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: You say very true sister Delia, and I prithee call me nothing but Tom and I'll call thee sweetheart, and Frank: will it not do well sister Delia?

sp.speaker: Delia.
sp.p: It will do very well with both of you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But Tom, must I go as I do now when I am married?

lg.l: No Francke, I'll have thee go like a citizen
In a guarded gown, and a french-hood.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By my troth that will be excellent indeed.

lg.l: Brother, maintain your wife to your estate,
Apparel you yourself like to your father:
And let her go like to your ancient mother,
He sparing got his wealth, left it to you,
Brother take heed of pride, some bids thrift adieu.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: So as my father and my mother went, that's a jest indeed, why she went in a fringed gown, a single ruff, and a white cap.
And my father in a mocado coat, a pair of red satin sleeves, and a canvas back.

sp.speaker: Delia.
sp.p: And yet his wealth was all as much as yours.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: My estate, my estate I thank God is forty pound a year, in good leases and tenements, besides twenty mark a year at cuckolds-haven, and that comes to us all by inheritance.

lg.l: That may indeed, 'tis very fitly plied,
I know not how it comes, but so it falls out
That those whose fathers have died wondrous rich,
And took no pleasure but to gather wealth,
Thinking of little that they leave behind:
For them they hope, will be of their like mind,
But falls out contrary, forty years sparing
Is scarce three seven years spending, never caring
What will ensue, when all their coin is gone,
And all too late, than thrift is thought upon:
Oft have I heard, that pride and riot kissed,
And then repentance cries, for had I wist.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: You say well sister Delia, you say well: but I mean to live within my bounds: for look you, I have set down my rest thus far, but to maintain my wife in her french-hood, and her coach, keep a couple of geldings, and a brace of grey hounds, and this is all I'll do.

sp.speaker: Delia.
sp.p: And you'll do this with forty pound a year?

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: Ay, and a better penny sister.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sister you forget that at 〈◊〉.

lg.l: By my troth well remembered 〈◊〉,
〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 that to buy thee 〈◊〉.
Keep you the rest for points, alas the day,
Fools shall have wealth, though all the world say nay:
Come brother will you in, dinner stays for us.

sp.p: I good sister with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I by my troth Tom, for I have a good stomach.

lg.l: And I the like sweet Francke, no sister
Do not think I'll go beyond my bounds.

sp.speaker: Delia.
sp.p: God grant you may not.

div.stage: Enter young flowerdale and his father, with foils in their hands.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Sirrah Kit, tarry thou there, I have spied sir Lancelot, and old Weathercock coming this way, they are hard at hand, I will by no means be spoken with all.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: I'll warrant you, go get you in.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Now my honest friend, thou dost belong to master Flowerdale?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: I do sir.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Is he within my good fellow?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: No sir he is not within.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I prithee if he be within, let me speak with him.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Sir to tell you true, my master is within, but indeed would not be spoke withal: there be some terms that stands upon his reputation, therefore he will not admit any conference till he hath shaken them off.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I prithee tell him his very good friend sir Lancelot Spurcock, entreats to speak with him.
By my troth sir, if you come to take up the matter between my master and the Devonshire man, you do but beguile your hopes, and lose your 〈◊〉.
Honest friend, I have not any such thing to him, I come to speaked with him about other matters.

lg.l: For my master sir hath set down his resolution,
Either to redeem his honour, or leave his life behind him ▪

sp.p:
My friend I do not know any quarrel, touching
thy master or any other person, my business is of a different nature to him, and I prithee so tell him.

lg.l: For howsoever the Devonshireman is, my master's
Mind is bloody: that's a round O.
And therefore sir, entreaty is sir:

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I have no such thing to him, I tell thee once again.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: I will then so signify to him.

lg.l: A sirrah, I see this matter is hotly carried,
But I'll labour to dissuade him from it,Enter Flowerdale.
Good morrow master. Flowerdale.
Good morrow good sir Lancelot, good morrow master Weathercock.
By my troth gentlemen, I have been a reading over
Nick Machiavel, I find him
Good to be known, not to be followed:
A pestilent humane fellow, I have made
Certain anatations of him such as they be:
And how is't sir Lancelot? ha? how sir?
A mad world, men cannot live quiet in it.
Master Flowerdale, I do understand there is some jar
Between the Devonshire man and you.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: They sir? They are good friends as can be.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Who master Oliver and I? as good friends as can be.

lg.l: It is a kind of safety in you to deny it, and a generous
Silence, which too few are induced withal: but sir, such
A thing I hear, and I could wish it otherwise.
No such thing sir Lancelot, a my reputation,
As I am an honest man.
Now I do believe you then, if you do
Engage your reputation there is none.
Nay I do not engage my reputation there is not,
You shall not bind me to any condition of hardness:
But if there be any thing between us, then there is,
If there be not, than there is not: be or be not, all is one.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I do perceive by this, that there is something between you, and I am very sorry for it.

lg.l: You may be deceived sir Lancelot, the Italian
Hath a pretty saying, questo? I have forgotten it too,
'Tis out of my head, but in my translation
〈◊〉 hold thus, thou hast a friend, keep him.
Come, I do see by this there is somewhat between if a foe, trip him.
And before God I could wish it otherwise.
Well what is between us, can hardly be altered: you,
Sir Lancelot, I am to ride forth tomorrow,
That way which I must ride, no man must deny
Me the sun, I would not by any particular man,
Be denied common and general passage. If any one
Saith Flowerdale, thou passest not this way:
My answer is, I must either on or return,
But return is not my word, I must on:
If I cannot, then make my way, nature
Hath done the last for me, and there's the fine.
Master Flowerdale, every man hath one tongue,
And two ears, nature in her building,
Is a most curious workmaster.
That is as much to say, a man should hear more
Than he should speak.
You say true, and indeed I have heard more,
Than at this time I will speak,

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: You say well.

lg.l: Slanders are more common than troths master Flowerdale?
But proof is the rule for both.
You say true, what do you call him
Hath it there in his third canton?

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I have heard you have been wild: I have believed it.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: 'Twas fit, 'twas necessary.

lg.l: But I have seen somewhat of late in you,
That hath confirmed in me an opinion of
Goodness towards you.
I'faith sir, I am sure I never did you harm:
Some good I have done, either to you or yours,
I am sure you know not, neither is it my will you should.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I your will sir.

lg.l: I my will sir 'sfoot do you know ought of my will?
Be-god and you do sir, I am abused.

sp.speaker: Lance.

lg.l: Go master Flowerdale, what I know, I know,
And know you thus much out of my knowledge,
That I truly love you. For my daughter,
she yours. And if you like a marriage better

sp.p: Then a brawl, all quirks of reputation set aside, go with me presently: and where you should fight a bloody battle, you shall be married to a lovely lady,

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Nay but sir Lancelot?

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: If you will not embrace my offer yet assure yourself thus much, I will have order to hinder your encounter.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Nay but hear me sir Lancelot.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Nay stand not you upon imputative honour.
'Tis merely unsound, unprofitable, and idle:
Inferences your business is to wed my daughter therefore give me your present word to do it, I'll go and provide the maid, therefore give me your present resolution, either now, or never.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Will you so put me too it?

lg.l: I afore God, either take me now, or take me never,
Else what I thought should be our match, shall be our parting,
So fare you well for ever.
Stay: fall out, what may fall, my love
Is above all: I will come.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I expect you, and so fare you well.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Now sir, how shall we do for wedding apparel?

lg.l: By the mass that's true: now help Kit,
The marriage ended, we'll make amends for all.
Well no more, prepare you for your bride,
We will not want for clothes, whatsoe'er betide.
And thou shalt see, when once I have my dower,
In mirth we'll spend,
Full many a merry hour:
As for this wench, I not regard a pin,
It is her gold must bring my pleasures in.
Is't possible, he hath his second living ▪
Forsaking God, himself to the devil giving
But that I knew his mother firm and chaste ▪
My heart would say, my head she had disgraced:
Else would I swear, he never was my son,
But her fair mind so foul a deed did shun,

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: How now brother, how do you find your son?

lg.l: O brother, heedless as a libertine,
Even grown a master in the school of vice,
One that doth nothing, but invent deceit:
For all the day he humours up and down,
How he the next day 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 his friend,
He thinks of nothing but the present time:
For one groat ready down, he'll pay a shilling,
But then the lender must needs stay for it.
When I was young, I had the scope of youth,
Both wild, and wanton, careless and desperate:
But such mad strains, as he's possessed withal,
I thought it wonder for to dream upon.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: I told you so, but you would not believe it.

lg.l: Well I have found it, but one thing comforts me.
Brother, tomorrow he's to be married
To beauteous Luce, sir Lancelot's Spurcock's daughter.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Is't possible?

lg.l: 'Tis true, and thus I mean to curb him,
This day brother, I will you shall arrest him:
If any thing will tame him, it must be that,
For he is rank in mischief, chained to a life,
That will increase his shame, and kill his wife.
What, arrest him on his wedding day?
That were unchristian, and an unhuman part:
How many couple even for that very day,
Hath purchased years sorrow afterwards?
Forbear him then today, do it tomorrow,
And this day mingle not his joy with sorrow.
Brother I'll ha● it done this very day,
And in the view of all, as he comes from church ▪
Do but observe the course that he will take,
Upon my life he will forswear the debt:
And for we'll have the sum shall not be slight,
Say that he owes you neere three thousand pound:
Good brother let be done immediately:
Well, seeing you will have it so ▪
Brother I'll do't, and straight provide the sheriff.
So brother, by this means shall we perceive
What sir Lancelot in this pinch will do:
And how his wife doth stand affected too him ▪
Her love will then be tried to the uttermost:
And all the rest of them ▪ brother what I will do,
Shall harm him much, and much avail him too.
Cham ashured thick be the place, that the scoundrel
Appointed to meet me, if a come ●o: if 'a come not, zo ▪
And che war avise, he should make a coistrel an us,
Ched vese him, and che vang him in hand, che would
Hoist him, and give it him too ▪ and again, zo chud:
Who been a there sir Arthur, Chil stay aside.
I have dogged the Devonshire man into the field ▪
For fear of any harm that should befall him:
I had an inkling of that yesternight,
That Flowerdale and he should meet this morning ▪
Though of my soul, Oliver fears him not,
Yet for I'd see fair play on either side,
Made me to come, to see their valours tried ▪
Good morrow to master Oliver.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: God an good morrow.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: What master Ol●r are you angry ▪

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Why an it be ▪ tyt and grieven you ▪

lg.l: Not me at all sir ▪ but I imagine
By your being here thus armed,
You stay for some that you should fight withal ▪

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Why and he do, che would not desire you to take his part.

lg.l: No by my troth, I think you need it not,
For he you look for, I think means not to come.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: No and che war assure a that, ch●d 〈◊〉 him in another place.

lg.l: O sir Arthur, master Oliver Ayeme ▪(Enter 〈◊〉.
Your love, and yours, and mine, sweet mistress Luce,
This morn is married to young Flowerdale.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Married to Flowerdale! 'tis impossible.

lg.l: Married man ▪ che hope thou dost but jest:
to make an a volowten merriment of it.

sp.speaker: Daf.
sp.p: O 'tis too true. Here comes his uncle.

sp.speaker: Uncl●.
sp.p: Good morrow sir Arthur, good morrow m. Oliver.

lg.l: God and good morn m. Oliver. I pray you tellen
Is your scoundrel kinsman married?
M. Oliver, call him what you will, but he is married us,
To sir Lancelot's daughter here.

sp.speaker: Uncle.
sp.p: Sir Arthur, unto her ▪

lg.l: Ay, ha the old vellow zarved me thick trick,
Why man he was a promise, Chil chud 'a had her,
Is a zitch a voxe, Chill look to his water che warrant him.
The music plays, they are coming from the church.
Sheriff do your office: fellows, stand stoutly too it ▪

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: God give you joy, as the old zaid proverb is, and some zorrow among. You met us well ▪ did you not?

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Nay be not angry sir, the fault is in me, I have done all the wrong, kept him from coming to the field to you ▪ as I might sir, for I am a justice, and sworn to keep the peace.

sp.speaker: Whe.
sp.p: I marry is he sir, a very justice, and sworn to keep the peace, you must not disturb the weddings.

lg.l: Nay, never frown nor storm sir, if you do,
I'll have an order taken for you.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Well, well, Chill be quiet.

sp.speaker: Whe.
sp.p: M. Flowerdale, sir Lancelot, look you who here is? M. Flowerdale ▪

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: M. Flowerdale, welcome with all my heart.

lg.l: Uncle, this is she i'faith: master undersheriff
Arrest me? at whose suit? draw kit.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: At my suit sir ▪

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Why what's the matter m. Flowerdale?

lg.l: This is the matter sir, this unthrift here,
Hath cozened you, and hath had of me,
In several sums three thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Why uncle, uncle.

lg.l: Cousin, cousin, you have uncled me ▪
And if you be not stayed, you'll prove
A cozener unto all that know you.
Why sir, suppose he be to you in debt
Ten thousand pound, his state to me appear,
To be at least three thousand by the year.
O sir, I was too late informed of that plot,
How that he went about to cozen you ▪
And formed a will, and sent it to your good
Friend there master Weathercock, in which was
Nothing true, but brags and lies.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: H●, hath he not such lordships, lands, and ships?
Not worth a groat ▪ not worth a halfpenny he.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I pray tell us true, be plain young Flowerdale?

lg.l: My uncle here mad, and disposed to do me wrong,
But here's my man, an honest fellow
By the lord, and of good credit, knows all is true.
Not I sir ▪ I am too old to lie, I rather know
You forged a will, where every line you writ,
You studied where to coat your lands might lie.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: And I prithee, where be thy honest friends?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: i'faith nowhere sir, for he hath none at all.
Benedicite, we are o'er wretched I believe.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I am cozened, and my hopefullest child undone.

lg.l: You are not cozened, nor is she undone,
They slander me, by this light they slander me;
Look you, my uncle here's a● usurer ▪ and would undo me,
But I'll 〈◊〉 in law, do you but bail me, you shall do no more ▪
You brother Civet, and master Weathercock, do but
Bail me, and let me have my marriage money
Paid me, and we'll down, and there your own ▪
Eyes shall see, how my poor tenants there will welcome me ▪
You shall but bail me, you shall do no more,
And you greedy gnat, their bail will serve.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: I sir, I'll, ask no better bail,

lg.l: No sir you shall not take my bail, nor his,
Nor my son Civet, I'll not be chea● I,
Shreeve take your prisoner, I'll not deal with him ▪
let's uncle make false dice with his false bones,
I will not have to do with him: mocked, gulled, and wronged.
Come girl, though it be late it falls out well,
Thou shalt not live with him in beggar's hell.
He is my husband, and high heaven doth know,
With what unwillingness I went to church,
But you enforced me, you compelled me too it:
The holy churchman pronounced these words but now,
I must not leave my husband in distress:
Now I must comfort him, not go with you.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: Comfort a cozener? on my curse forsake him.

lg.l: This day you caused me on your curse to take him:
Do not I pray my grieved soul oppress,
God knows my heart doth bleed at his distress.
O m. Weathercock, I must confess I forced her to this match,
Led with opinion his false will was true.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: A, he hath overreached me too.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: She might have lived like Delia, in a happy virgin's state.

sp.speaker: Delia.
sp.p: Father be patient, sorrow comes too late.

lg.l: And on her knees she begged and did entreat,
If she must needs taste a sad marriage life,
She craved to be sir Arthur Greenshield's wife.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: You have done her and me the greater wrong.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: O take her yet.

sp.speaker: Arthur.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: Or, m. Oliver, except my child, and half my wealth is yours.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: No sir, Chil break no laws.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Never fear, she will not trouble you.

sp.speaker: Delia.
sp.p: Yet sister in this passion do not run headlong to confusion. You may affect him, though not follow him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Do sister, hang him, let him go.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Do faith mistress Luce, leave him.

lg.l: You are three gross fools, let me alone,
I swear I'll live with him in all moan.
But an he have his legs at liberty,
Cham averd he will never live with you.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I but he is now in hucksters handling for running away.

lg.l: Housewife, you hear how you and I am wronged,
And if you will redress it yet you may:
But if you stand on terms to follow him,
Never come near my sight nor look on me,
Call me not father, look not for a groat,
For all thy portion I will this day give
Unto thy sister Frances.
How say you to that Tom, I shall have a good deal,
Besides I'll be a good wife: and a good wife
Is a good thing, I can tell.
Peace Frank, I would be sorry to see thy sister
Cast away, as I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: What, are you yet resolved?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: Come then away, or now, or never come.

lg.l: This way I turn, go you unto your feast,
And I to weep, that am with grief oppressed.
For ever fly my sight: come gentleman
Let's in, I'll help you to far better wives than her.
Delia upon my blessing talk not too her,
Base baggage, in such haste to beggary?

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Sheriff take your prisoner to your charge.

lg.l: Uncle, be-god you have used me very hardly,
By my troth, upon my wedding day.

div.stage: Exit all: young Flowerdale, his father, uncle, sheriff, and officers.

lg.l: O m. Flowerdale, but hear me speak,
Stay but a little while good m. sheriff,
If not for him, for my sake pity him:
Good sir stop not your ears at my complaint,
My voice grows weak, for women's words are faint.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Look you uncle, she kneels to you.

lg.l: Fair maid, for you, I love you with my heart,
And grieve sweet soul thy fortune is so bad,
That thou shouldst match with such a graceless youth,
Go to thy father, think not upon him,
Whom hell hath marked to be the son of shame.
Impute his wildness sir, unto his youth,
And think that now is the time he doth repent:
Alas, what good or gain can you receive,
To imprison him that nothing hath to pay?
And where naught is, the King doth lose his due,
Oh pity him as God shall pity you.
Lady, I know his humours all too well,
And nothing in the world can do him good,
But misery itself to chain him with.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Say that your debts were paid, then is he free?

lg.l: I virgin, that being answered, I have done,
But to him that is all as impossible,
As I to scale the high pyramids.
Sheriff take your prisoner, maiden fare thee well.
O go not yet, good m. Flowerdale:
Take my word for the debt, my word, my bond.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: I by God uncle, and my bond too.

lg.l: Alas, I ne'er ought nothing but I paid it,
And I can work, alas he can do nothing:
I have some friends perhaps will pity me,
His chiefest friends do seek his misery.
All that I can, or beg, get, or receive,
Shall be for you: oh do not turn away,
Methinks within a face so reverent,
So well experienced in this tottering world,
Should have some feeling of a maiden's grief:
For my sake, his fathers, and your brother's sake,
I for your soul's sake that doth hope for joy,
Pity my state: do not two souls destroy.
Fair maid stand up, not in regard of him,
But in pity of thy hapless choice,
I do release him, m. sheriff I thank you:
And officers there is for you to drink.
Here maid take this money, there is a 100. Angels,
And for I will be sure he shall not have it,
Here Kester take it you, and use it sparingly,
But let not her have any want at all.
Dry your eyes niece, do not too much lament
For him, whose life hath been in riot spent:
If well he useth thee, he gets him friends,
If ill ▪ a shameful end on him depends.
A plague go with you for an old fornicator:
Come Kit the money, come honest Kit.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Nay by my faith sir, you shall pardon me.

lg.l: And why sir pardon you? give me the money
You old rascal, or I shall make you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray hold your hands, give it him honest friend.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: If you be so content, with all my heart.

lg.l: Content sir, 'sblood she shall be content
Whether she will or no. A rattle baby come to follow me:
Go get you gone to the greasy chuff your father,
Bring me your dowry, or never look on me.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Sir she hath forsook her father, and all her friends for you.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Hang thee, her friends and father altogether.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Yet part with something to provide her lodging.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes, I mean to part with her and you, but if I part with one angel, hang me at a post. I'll rather throw them at a cast at dice, as I have done a thousand of their fellows.

lg.l: Nay then I will be plain degenerate boy,
Thou hadst a father would have been a shamed.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: My father was an ass, an old ass.

lg.l: Thy father? proud licentious villain:
What are you at your foils, I'll foil with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Good sir for bear him.

lg.l: Did not this whining woman hang on me,
I'd teach thee what it was to abuse thy father:
Go hang, beg, starve, dice, game, that when all is gone
Thou mayst after despair and hang thyself.

sp.speaker: Luee.
sp.p: O do not curse him.

lg.l: I do not curse him, and to pray for him were vain,
It grieves me that he bears his father name.
Well you old rascal, I shall meet with you,
Sirrah get you gone, I will not strip the livery
Over your ears, because you paid for it:
But do not use my name, sirrah do you hear? look you do not
Use my name, you were best.
Pay me the twenty pound then, that I lent you,
Or give me security, when I may have it.
I'll pay thee not a penny, and for security, I'll give thee none,
Minckins look you do not follow me, look you do not:
If you do beggar, I shall slit your nose.

sp.speaker: Lnce.
sp.p: Alas what shall I do?

lg.l: Why turn whore, that's a good trade,
And so perhaps I'll see thee now and then.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Alas the day that ever I was born.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Sweet mistress do not weep, I'll stick to you.

lg.l: Alas my friend, I know not what to do,
My father and my friends, they have despised me:
And I a wretched maid, thus cast away,
Knows neither where to go, nor what to say.
It grieves me at the soul, to see her tears
Thus stain the crimson roses of her cheeks:
Lady take comfort, do not mourn in vain,
I have a little living in this town,
The which I think comes to a hundred pound,
All that and more shall be at your dispose,
I'll straight go help you to some strange disguise,
And place you in a service in this town:
where you shall know all, yet yourself unknown:
Come grieve no more, where no help can be had,
Weep not for him, that is more worse than bad.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

div.stage: Enter sir Lancelot, master 〈◊〉 and them.

lg.l: Well, Cha a been zerved many a sluttish trick,
But such a lerripoop as thick ych was ne'er a sarved.
Son Civet, daughter Frances, bear with me,
You see how I am pressed down with inward grief,
About that luckless girl, your sister Luce:
But 'tis fallen out with me, as with many families beside,
They are most unhappy, that are most belove.
Father 'tis so, 'tis even fallen out so,
But what remedy, set hand to your heart, and let it pass:
Here is your daughter Frances and I, and we'll not say,
We'll bring forth as witty children, but as pretty
Children as ever she was: though she had the prick
And praise for a pretty wench: but father, done is
The mouse, you'll come?

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I son Civet, I'll come.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: And you master Oliver?

lg.l: Ay, for che a vexed out this veast, Chill see if again
Make a better veast there.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: And you sir Arthur?

lg.l: I sir, although my heart be full,
I'll be a partner at your wedding feast.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: And welcome all indeed, and welcome, come Frank are you ready?

lg.l: Jeshue how hasty these husbands are, I pray father,
Pray to God to bless me.
God bless thee, and I do: God make thee wise,
Send you both joy, I wish it with wet eyes.
But father, shall not my sister Delia go along with us?
She is excellent good at cookery and such things.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Yes marry shall she: Delia, make you ready.

lg.l: I am ready sir, I will first go to Greenwich,
From thence to my cousin Chesterfield's, and so to London.
It shall suffice good sister Delia, it shall suffice,
But fail us not good sister, give order to cooks, and others,
For I would not have my sweet Francke
To soil her fingers.
No by my troth not I, a gentlewoman, and a married
Gentlewoman too, to be companions to cooks,
And kitchen-boys, not I, i'faith: I scorn that.
Why I do not mean thou shalt sweet heart,
Thou seest I do not go about it: well farewell too:
You, gods pity m. Weathercock, we shall have your company too?

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Withal my heart, for I love good cheer.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: Well, God be with you all, come Frank.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: God be with you father, God be with you sir Arthur, master Oliver, and master Weathercock, sister, God be with you all: God be with you father, God be with you every one.

lg.l: Why how now sir Arthur? all a mort master Oliver, how now man?
Cheerly sir Lancelot, and merrily say,
Who can hold that will away.
I she is gone indeed, poor girl undone,
But when they'll be self-willed, children must smart.
But sir, that she is wronged, you are the chiefest cause.
Therefore 'tis reason, you redress her wrong.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Indeed you must sir Lancelot, you must.

lg.l: Must? who can compel me master Weathercock ▪
I hope I may do what I list.

sp.speaker: Vvea.
sp.p: I grant you may, you may do what you list.

lg.l: Nay, but and you be well evisen, it were not good
By this frampolness, and frowardness, to cast away
As pretty a Dowsabel, as am chould chance to see
in a summer's day, Chil tell you what chall do,
Chil go spy up and down the town, and see if I
Can hear any tale or dydings of her,
And take her away from thick a mesel, vor Cham
Ashured, he'll but bring her to the spoil,
And so var you well, we shall meet at your son Civets.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: I thank you sir, I take it very kindly.

lg.l: To find her out, I'll spend my dearest blood. Exit both.
So well I loved her, to affect her good.
O master weathercock, what hap had I, to force my daughter
From master Oliver, and this good knight?
To one that hath no goodness in his thought.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Ill luck, but what remedy.

lg.l: Yes I have almost devised a remedy,
Young Flowerdale, is sure a prisoner.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Sure, nothing more sure.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: And yet perhaps his uncle hath released him.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: It may be very like, no doubt he hath.

lg.l: Well if he be in prison, I'll have warrant
To attach my daughter till the law be tried,
For I will sue him upon cozenage.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Marry may you, and overthrow him too▪

lg.l: Nay that's not so, I may chance be sco●,
And sentence passed with him.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Believe me so he may, therefore take heed.

lg.l: Well howsoever, yet I will have warrants,
In prison, or at liberty, all's one:
You will help to serve them master weathercock?
A plague of the devil, the devil take the dice,
The dice, and the devil, and his dam go together:
of all my hundred golden angels,
I have not left me one denier:
A poke of come a five, what shall I do?
I can borrow no more of my credit:
There's not any of my acquaintance, man, nor boy,
But I have borrowed more or less off:
I would I knew where to take a good purse,
And go clear away, by this light I'll venture for it,
God's lid my sister Delia,
I'll rob her, by this hand.
I prithee Artichoake go not so fast,
The weather is hot, and I am something weary.
Nay I warrant you mistress Delia I'll not tire you
With leading, we'll go an extreme moderate pace.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Stand, deliver your purse.

sp.speaker: Artichoake
sp.p: O lord, thieves, thieves.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Come, come, your purse lady, your purse.

lg.l: That voice I have heard often before this time,
What brother Flowerdale, become a thief?
Ay, a plague on't, I thank your father,
But sister, come, your money, come:
What the world must find me, I am born to live,
'Tis not a sin to steal, when none will give.
O God, is all grace banished from thy heart,
Think of the shame that doth attend this fact.
Shame me no shames, come give me your purse,
I'll bind you sister, lest I fair the worse.
No, bind me not, hold there is all I have,
And would that money would redeem thy shame.

div.stage: Enter Oliver sir Arthur, and Artichoake.

sp.speaker: Artichoake
sp.p: Thieves, thieves, thieves.

lg.l: Thieves, where man? why how now mistress Delia,
Ha you a liked to been a-robbed ?

sp.speaker: Delia.
sp.p: No master Oliver, 'tis master Flowerdale, he did but jest with me.

lg.l: How, Flowerdale, that scoundrel sirrha◊, you me●en us
Well, vang thee that.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Well sin, I'll not meddle with you, because I have a charge.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Here brother Flowerdale I'll lend you this same money ▪

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: I thank you sister.

lg.l: I would you were ysplit, and you let the mesel have a penny,
But since you cannot keep it, Chil keep it myself.
'Tis pity to relieve him in this sort,
Who makes a triumphant life, his daily sport.
Brother, you see how all men censure you,
Farewell, and I pray God amend your life.
Come, Chill bring you along, and you safe enough
From twenty such scoundrels as thick a one is,
Farewell and be hanged zyrrha, as I think so thou
Wilt be shortly, come sir Arthur.
A plague go with you for a karsy rascal:
This Devonshire many I think is made all of pork,
His hands made only, for to heave up packs:
His heart as fat and big as his face,
As differing far from all brave gallant minds
As I to serve the hogs, and drink with hinds,
As I am very near now: well, what remedy,
When money, means, and friends, do grow so small,
Then farewell life, and there's an end of all.

div.stage: Enter father, Luce like a Dutch Frow, civet, and his wife 〈◊〉 Frances.

lg.l: By my troth god a mercy for this good Christopher,
I thank thee for my maid, I like her very well,
How dost thou like her Frances?
In good sadness Tom, very well, excellent well,
She speaks so prettily, I pray what's your name?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: My name forsooth be called Tanikin.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By my troth a fine name, oh Tanikin, you are excellent for dressing one head a new fashion.
Me sall do every ting about da head.

sp.speaker: Ci●.
sp.p: What countrywoman is she Kester?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: A Dutch woman sir.

sp.speaker: Ci●.
sp.p: Why then she is outlandish, is she not?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: I sir she is.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O then thou canst tell how to help me to cheeks and ears

sp.speaker: Luc●.
sp.p: Yes mistress very vell.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Cheeks and ears, why mistress Frances, want you cheeks and ears? methinks you have very fair ones.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Thou art a fool indeed Tom, thou knowest what I mean,

lg.l: Ay, i Kester, 'tis such as they wear a their heads,
I prithee Kit have her in, and show her my house.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: I will sir, come Tanikin.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O Tom, you have not bussed me today Tom.

sp.speaker: Ci●.

lg.l: No Frances, we must not kiss afore folks,
God save me Frank,

sp.p: See yonder my sister Delia is come, welcome good sister.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Welcome good sister, how do you like the tier of my head?

sp.speaker: Delia.
sp.p: Very well sister.

sp.speaker: Ci●.
sp.p: I am glad you're come sister Delia to give order for supper, they will be here soon.

lg.l: Ay, but if good luck had not served, she had
Not been here now, filching Flowerdale had like
To peppord us, but for master Oliver, we had been robbed.

sp.speaker: De●.
sp.p: Peace sirrah, no more.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Robbed by whom?

sp.speaker: Artichoke
sp.p: Marry by none but by Flowerdale, he is turned thief.

lg.l: By my faith, but that is not well, but God be praised
For your escape, will you draw near sister?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Sirrah come hither, would Flowerdale, ●ee that was my master, a robbed you, I prithee tell me true?

sp.speaker: Artichoke
sp.p: Yes i'faith ▪ even that Flowerdale, that was thy master.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Hold thee, there is a French crown, and speak no more of this.

lg.l: Not I, not a word, now do I smell knaverie:
In every purse Flowerdale takes, he is half ▪
And gives me this to keep counsel, ●o not a word I.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Why God a mercy.

lg.l: Sister look here, I have a new Dutch maid,
And she speaks so fine, it would do your heart good.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: How do you like her sister?
I like your maid well.

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: Well dear sister, will you draw near, and give directions for supper, guess will be here presently.

sp.speaker: Delia.
sp.p: Yes brother, lead the way I'll follow you.
sp.stage: Exit all but Delia and Luce.
sp.p: Hark you Dutch frowe a word.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Vat is your vill wi● me?

lg.l: Sister Luce ▪ 'tis not your broken language,
Nor this same habit, can disguise your face
From I that know you: pray tell me, what means this?
Sister, I see you know me, yet be secret:
This borrowed shape, that I have tan● upon me,
Is but to keep myself, a space unknown ,
Both from my father, and my nearest friends ▪
Until I see, how time will bring to pass,
The desperate course, of master Flowerdale.
O he is worse than bad, I prithee leave him ▪
And let not once thy heart to think on him.
Do not persuade me, once to such a thought,
Imagine yet, that he is worse than naught:
Yet one lovers time, may all that ill undo,
That all his former life, did run into ▪
therefore kind sister do not disclose my estate,
If ere his heart doth turn, 'tis never too late.
Well, seeing no counsel can remove your mind,
I'll not disclose you, that art wilful blind.
Delia, I thank you, I now must please her eyes,
My sister Frances, neither fair nor wise.
On goes he that knows no end of his journey,
I have passed the 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 bounds of shifting,
I have no course now but to hang myself:
I have lived since yesterday two o'clock , of a
Spice-cake I had at a burial ▪ and for drink,
I got it at an alehouse among porters, as as
Will bear out a man, if he have no money indeed.
I mean out of their companies, for they are men
Of good carriage. Who comes here?
The two coney-catchers, that won all my money of me.
I'll try if they'll lend me any.
What m. Richard how do you?
How dost thou Rafe? By God gentlemen the world
Grows bare with me, will you do as much as lend
Me an angel between you both, you know you
Won a hundred of me the other day.
Ho● ▪ angel? God damn us if we lost not every
Penny, within an hour after thou wert gone.
I prithee lend me so much as will pay for my supper,
I'll pay you again, as I am a gentleman.
I'faith, we have have not a farthing, not a mite:
I ▪ wonder at it m. Flowerdale,
You will so carelessly undo yourself,
Why you will lose more money in an hour,
than any honestman spend in a year,
For shame betake you to some honest trade,
And live not thus so like a vagabond.
A vagabond indeed, more villain's you●
They gave me counsel that first cozened me:
Those devils first brought me to this I am,
And being thus, the first that do me wrong.
Well, yet I have one friend left in store,
Not far from hence, there dwells a cockatrice,
One that I first put in a satin gown,
And not a tooth that dwell within her head,
But stands me at the least in 20 ▪ pound:
Her will I visit now my coin is gone,
And as I take it here dwells the gentlewomen.
What ho, is mistress 〈◊〉 within?
What saucy rascal is that which knocks so bold,
Oh, is it your old spend ▪ thrist, are you here?
One 'That is turned cozener about thee to 〈◊〉 ▪
My mistress saw you, and sends this lord by me ▪
Either be packing quickly from the door,
Or you shall have such a greeting sent you straight,
As you will little like on, you had best be gone.
Why so, this is as it should be, being poor,
Thus art thou served by a vile painted whore.
Well, since thy damned crew do so abuse thee,
I'll try of honest men, how they will use me.
Sir I beseech you to take compassion of a man,
One whose fortunes have been better than at this instant
They seem to be ': but if I might crave of you so much little
Portion, as would bring me to my friends, I should rest
Thankful, until I had requited so great a courtesy.
Fie, fie, young man, this course is very bad,
Too many such have we about this city,
Yet for I have not seen you in this sort,
Nor noted you to be a common beggar:
Hold there's an angel, to bear your charges,
Down, go to your friends, do not on this depend,
Such bad beginnings oft have worser ends.

sp.speaker: Flow.

lg.l: Worse ends: nay, if it fall out
No worse than in old angels I care not,
Nay now I have had such a fortunate beginning,
I'll not let a: sixpenny-purse escape me,
By the mass, here comes another.

sp.stage: Enter a citizen's wife with a torch before her.

lg.l: God bless you fair mistress.
Now would it please you gentlewoman to look into the
Wants of a poor gentleman, a younger brother, I doubt not
