But God will triple restore it back again, one that never
Before this time demanded penny, halfpenny, nor farthing.

sp.p: Wife. Stay Alexander, now by my troth a very proper man, and 'tis great pity: hold my friend, there's all the money I have about me, a couple of shillings, and God bless thee.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Now God thank you sweet lady: if you have any friend, or garden-house, where you may employ a poor gentleman as your friend, I am yours to command in all secret service.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I thank you good friend, I prithee let me see that again, I gave thee, there is one of them a brass shilling, give me them, and here is half a crown in gold. He gives it her. Now out upon thee rascal, secret service: what dost thou make of me? it were a good deed to have thee whipped: now I have my money again, I'll see thee hanged before I give thee a penny: secret service: on good Alexander.

lg.l: This is villainous luck, I perceive dishonesty
Will not thrive: here comes more. God forgive me,
Sir Arthur, and m. Oliver, afore God, I'll speak to them,
God save you sir Arthur ▪ God save you m. Oliver.
Been you there zyrrah, come will you ytaken yourself
To your tools, coistrel??
Nay, m. Oliver, I'll not fight with you,
Alas sir you know it was not my doings,
It was only a plot to get sirrha 〈◊〉 daughter:
By God, I never meant you harm.
And whore is the gentlewoman thy wife, mesel?
Whore is she, sirrah, ha
By my troth m. Oliver, sick, very sick;
And God is my judge, I know not what means to make for her, good gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Tell me true, is she sick? tell me true i●ch ●ise thee?

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Yes faith, I tell you true: m. Oliver, if you would do me the small kindness, but to lend me forty shillings: so God help me I will pay you ●o soon as my ability shall make me able, as I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Well thou zaist thy wife is zick: hold, there's vorty shillings, gived it to thy wife, look thou give it her, or I shall zo veze thee, thou wert not so vezed this zeven year, look too it.

lg.l: I'faith m. Oliver, it is in vain
To give to him that never thinks of her ▪

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Well, would che could 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 ▪

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: I tell you true, sir Arthur, as I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Well fare you well zyrrah: come sir Arthur.

lg.l: By the lord this is excellent.
Five golden angels compassed in an hour,
If this trade hold, I'll never seek a new.
Welcome sweet gold: and beggary adieu.

sp.p: See Kester if you can find the house.

lg.l: Who's here, my uncle, and my man Kester?
By the mass 'tis they.
How do you uncle, how dost thou Kester?
By my troth uncle, you must needs lend
Me some money, the poor gentlewoman
My wife, so God help me, is very sick,
I was robbed of the hundred angels
You gave me, they are gone.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: I they are gone indeed, come Kester away.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Nay uncle, do you hear? good uncle.

lg.l: Out hypocrite, I will not hear thee speak,
Come leave him Kester.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Kester, honest Kester.

lg.l: Sir, I have thought to say to you,
Open the door to my kin, thou hadst best
Locked fast, for there's a false knave without.
You are an old lying rascal,
So you are.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Vat is de matter, vat be you younker?

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: By this light a Dutch froe, they say they are called kind, by this light I'll try her.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Vat been you younker, why do you not speak?

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: By my troth sweet heart, a poor gentleman that would desire of you, if it stand with your liking, the bounty of your purse.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O here God, so young an armine.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Armine sweetheart, I know not what you mean by that, but I am almost a beggar.

lg.l: Are you not a married man, vere been your vife?
Here is all I have, take dis.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: What gold young froe? this is brave.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: If he have any grace, he'll now repent ▪

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Why speak you not, were be your 〈◊〉?

lg.l: Dead, dead, she's dead, 'tis she hath undone me,
Spent me all I had, and kept 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 mine nose to brave me.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Did you use her vell?

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Use her, there's never a gentlewoman in England could be better used then I did, I could but coach her, her diet stood me in forty pound a month, but she is dead and in her grave, my cares are buried.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Indeed dat vas not scone.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: He is turned more devil than he was before.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Thou dost belong to master civet here, dost thou not?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Yes me do.

lg.l: Why there's it, there's not a handful of plate
But belongs to me, god's my judge:
If I had but such a wench as thou art,
There's never a man in England would make more
Of her, than I would do ▪ so she had any stock. They call within:
Oh why tannakin.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Stay one doth call, I shall come by and by again.

lg.l: By this hand, this Dutch wench is in love with me,
Were it not admiral to make her steal
All Civets plate, and run away.
'Twere beastly. O master Flowerdale,
Have you no fear of God, nor conscience:
What do you mean, by this vild course you take?

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: What do I mean, why to live, that I mean.

lg.l: To live in this sort, fie upon the course,
Your life doth show, you are a very coward.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: A coward, I pray in what?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Why you will borrow sixpence of a boy.

lg.l: Snails is there such cowardice in that, I dare
Borrow it of a man, I and of the tallest man ▪
In England, if he will lend it me,
Let me borrow it how I can, and let them come by it how they dare.
And it is well know, I rid out a hundred times
If I would: so I might.
It was not want of will, but cowardice,
There is none that lends to you, but know they gain:
And what is that but only stealth in you,
Delia might hang you now, did not her heart
Take pity of you for her sister's sake.
Go get you hence, lest lingering here you stay,
You fall into their hands you look not for.
I'll tarry here, till the Dutch froe
Comes, if all the devils in hell were here.

div.stage: Enter sir Lancelot, master Weathercock, and Artichoake.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Where is the door, are we not passed it Artichoake?

lg.l: Byth' mass here's one, I'll ask him, do you hear fir?
What are you so proud? do you hear, which is the way
To master Civets house? what will you not speak?
O me, this is filching Flowerdale.
O wonderful, is this lewd villain here?
O you cheating rogue, you cutpurse coney-catcher,
What ditch you villain, is my daughter's grave?
A cozening rascal, that must make a will,
Take on him that strict habit, very that:
When he should turn to angel, a dying grace,
I'll father in law you sir, I'll make a will,
Speak villain, where's my daughter?
Poisoned I warrant you, or knocked a the head:
And to abuse good master Weathercock, with his fordged will,
And master Weathercock, to make my grounded resolution,
Then to abuse the Devonshire gentlemen:
Go, away with him to prison.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Wherefore to prison? sir I will not go.

div.stage: Enter master Civet his wife, Oliver, sir Arthur, father, and uncle Delia ▪

lg.l: O here's his uncle, welcome gentlemen, welcome all,
Such a cozener gentlemen, a murderer too
For any thing I know, my daughter is missing:
Hath been looked for, cannot be found, a vild upon thee.
He is my kinsman, although his life be vild.
Therefore in god's name, do with him what you will.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Marry to prison.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Wherefore to prison? snick up, I owe you nothing.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Bring forth my daughter then, away with him.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Go seek your daughter, what do you lay to my charge,

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Suspicion of murder, go ▪ away with him.

lg.l: Murder your dogs, I murder your daughter,
Come uncle, I know you'll bail me.
Not I, were there no more.
Then I the jailor, thou the prisoner.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Go away with him.

lg.l: O my life here, where will you ha' de man?
Vat ha de younker done?

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Woman he hath killed his wife.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: His vife, dat is not good, dat is not seen.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Hang not upon him housewife, if you do I'll lay you by him.

lg.l: Have me no, and or way do you have him,
He tell me dat he love me heartily.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Lead away my maid to prison, why Tom will you suffer that?

sp.speaker: Ciu.
sp.p: No by your leave father, she is no vagrant:
She is my wife's chamber maid, and as true as the skin between any man's brows here.

lg.l: Go too, you're both fools: son cives,
Of my life this is a plot,
Some straggling counterfeit preferred to you:
No doubt to rob you of your plate and jewels,
I'll have you led away to prison trull.
I am no trull, neither outlandish frowe,
Nor he, nor I shall to the prison go:
Know you me now? nay never stand amazed.
Father I know I have offended you,
And though that duty wills me bend my knees
To you in duty and obedience:
Yet this ways do I turn, and to him yield
My love, my duty and my humbleness.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: Bastard in nature, kneel to such a slave?

lg.l: O m. Flowerdale, if too much grief
Have not stopped up the organs of your voice,
Then speak to her that is thy faithful wife,
Or doth contempt of me, thus tie thy tongue:
Turn not away, I am no Aesop,
No wanton Cressid, nor a changing Helen ▪
But rather one made wretched by thy loss.
What turnst thou still from me? O then
I guess thee woefull'st among hapless men.
I am indeed wife, wonder among wives!
Thy chastity and virtue hath infused
Another soul in me, red with defame,
For in my blushing cheeks is seen my shame.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: Out hypocrite, I charge thee trust him not.

lg.l: Not trust him, by hopes after bliss,
I know no sorrow can be compared to his.
Well since thou wert ordained to beggary,
Follow thy fortune, I defy thee I.

sp.speaker: O●.
sp.p: Ywood che were so well ydoussed as was ever white cloth in a stocking mill, and chea ha not made me weep.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: If he hath any grace he'll now repent.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: It moves my heart.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: By my troth I must weep, I can not choose.

sp.speaker: Uncle.
sp.p: None but a beast would such a maid misuse.

lg.l: Content thyself, I hope to win his favour,
And to redeem my reputation lost,
And gentlemen believe me, I beseech you,
I hope your eyes shall behold such change,
As shall deceive your expectation.

sp.speaker: O●.
sp.p: I would che were ysplit now, but che believe him.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: How, believe him.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: By the mackins, I do.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: What do you think that ere he will have grace?

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: By my faith it will go hard.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: Well che vorye he is changed ▪ and m. Flowerdale, in hope you been so, hold there's vorty pound towards your zetting up: what be not ashamed, vang it man, vang it, be a good husband, loven your wife ▪ and you shall not want for vorty more, I che vor thee.

lg.l: My means are little, but if you'll follow me,
I will instruct you in my ablest power:
But to your wife I give this diamond,
And prove true Dimond fair in all your life.
Thanks good sir Arthur, m. Oliver,
You being my enemy, and grown so kind,
Binds me in all endeavour to restore.

sp.speaker: Oly.

lg.l: What, restore me, no restorings man,
I have vorty pound more for Luce, here vang it.:
Zouth Chil defy 〈◊〉 else, what do not think me

sp.p: A mesel or a scoundrel to throw away my money ▪ che have a hundred pound more to 〈◊〉 of 〈◊〉 good spotation: I hope your under and your uncle here will vollow my examples.

sp.speaker: Uncle.
sp.p: You have guessed right of me, if he leave of this course of life, he shall be mine heir.

lg.l: But he shall never get a groat of me,
A cozener, a deceiver, one that killed his painful
Father, honest gentleman that passed the fearful
Danger of the sea, to get him living and maintain him brave.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: What hath he killed his father?

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Ay sir, with conceit of his vild courses.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Sir, you are misinformed.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: Why thou old knave, thou toldst me so thyself.

lg.l: I wronged him then: and towards my m. stock,
There's 20. Nobles for to make amends.
No Kester, I have troubled thee, and wrong thee more,
What thou in love gives, I in love restore.
Ha, ha, sister, there you played bopeep with
Tom, what shall I give her towards household?
Sister Delia, shall I give her my fan?

sp.p: You were best ask your husband.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Shall I tom ▪
I do frank I'll by thee a new one, with a longer handle.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A russet one Frank.

sp.speaker: Civit.
sp.p: I with russet feathers.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Here sister, there's my fan towards household, to keep you warm.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I thank, you sister.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: Why this is well, and towards fair Luce's stock, here's forty shillings: and forty good shillings more, I'll give her marry ▪ come sir Lancelot, I must have you friends.

lg.l: Not I ▪ all this is counterfeit,
He will consume it, were it a million.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Sir, what is your daughter's dower worth?

lg.l: Had she been married to an honest man,
It had been better than a thousand pound.
Pay it him, and I'll give you my bond,
To make her jointure better worth than three ▪

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: Your bond sir, why what are you?

lg.l: One whose word in London ●ho I say it,
Will pass there for as much as yours.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.p: Wert not thou late that unthrifts servingman?

lg.l: Look on me better, now my scar is off.
Ne'er muse man at this metamorphosy.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.p: M. Flowerdale.

lg.l: My father, oh I shame to look on him.
Pardon dear father the follies that are passed.
Son, son I do, and joy at this thy change,
And applaud thy fortune in this virtuous maid,
Whom heaven hath sent to thee to save thy soul.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This addeth joy to joy, hie heaven be praised.

lg.l: M. Flowerdale, welcome from death, good m. Flowerdale.
'Twas said so here, 'twas said so here good faith.
I caused that rumour to be spread myself ▪
Because I'd see the humours of my son,
Which to relate the circumstance is needless ▪
And sirrah see you run no more into that same disease:
For he that's once cured of that malady,
Of riot, swearing, drunkenness, and pride,
And falls again into the like distress,
That fever is deadly, doth till death endure:
Such men die mad as of a calenture.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Heaven helping me, I'll hate the course as hell.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Say it and do it cousin, all is well.

lg.l: Well being in hope you'll prove an honest man,
I take you to my favour brother Flowerdale,
Welcome with all my heart: I see your care
Hath brought these acts to this conclusion,
And I am glad of it, come let's in and feast.
Nay zoft you awhile, you promised to make
Sir Arthur and me amends, here is your wisest
Daughter, see which ans she'll have.

sp.speaker: Lane.
sp.p: A god's name, you have my good will, get hers.

sp.speaker: Oly.
sp.p: How say you the● damsel, tyters hate?

sp.speaker: Delia.
sp.p: Ay sir, am yours.

lg.l: Why, then send for a vicar, and Chil have it
Dispatched in a trice so chill.
Pardon me sir, I mean I am yours,
In love, in duty: and affection.
But not to love as wife, shall ne'er be said,
Delia was buried married, but a maid.
Do not condemn yourself for ever
Virtuous fair, you were born to love.
Why you say true sir Arthur she was ybere to it
So well as her mother ▪ but I pray you show us
Some zamples or reasons why you will not marry?
Not that I do condemn a married life,
For 'tis no doubt a sanctimonious thing:
But for the care and crosses of a wife,
The trouble in this world that children bring,
My vow is in heaven in earth to live alone,
Husbands howsoever good, I will have none.
Why then Chil will live bachelor too,
Che zet not a vig by a wife, if a wife zet not a vig
By me ▪ come shall's go to dinner?
Tomorrow I crave your companies in Marklane:
Tonight we'll frolic in m. Civets house,
And to each health, drink down a full carouse.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
